info.game_comments: 2005 Ultimate Tournament of Champions Round 2, game 9.

(1, 1).clue: When a bill reaches the President's desk, he may sign it, do nothing or do this

(2, 1).clue: Matthew Fox & 47 others survive a plane crash but are stranded on a mysterious Pacific island

(3, 1).clue: A knickerbocker cocktail contains gin, as well as the sweet & dry types of this

(4, 1).clue: This artist collaged color strips onto a photo of Mick Jagger & silkscreened them into prints

(6, 1).clue: Until 1999 the first snowfall signaled the start of the "Nude Olympics" at this university

(1, 2).clue: On Jan. 8, 2002 the President signed this act making schools more accountable

(2, 2).clue: On a primetime ABC soap, Teri Hatcher, Felicity Huffman & their neighbors on Wisteria Lane

(3, 2).clue: The bestselling imported liqueur in the U.S. is this coffee-flavored one from Mexico

(4, 2).clue: In 1933 Otto Dix was charged with obscenity by this political party; he was later drafted to fight for them

(6, 2).clue: Satan, Dracula & Ozzy Osbourne go by this nickname

(1, 3).clue: He was the first vice president who was born in Washington, D.C.

(2, 3).clue: The Kansas hamlet that's home to the Kents

(3, 3).clue: After imbibing this cocktail of gin or vodka & grapefruit juice, you'd better leave the driving to us

(4, 3).clue: Dirck, the younger brother of this "Laughing Cavalier" artist, was also big in Haarlem

(5, 3).clue: ...as Longacre Square, before a major metropolitian newspaper moved in

(6, 3).clue: This was the name given to the ship cast in the starring role on "The Love Boat"

(1, 4).clue: Sen. Ted Stevens of this state chairs the Commerce, Science & Transportation Committee

(2, 4).clue: Patricia Arquette, who sees dead people

(3, 4).clue: Peppermint & root beer are popular flavors of this strong potable, from the German for "mouthful"

(4, 4).clue: 16th century author Pietro Aretino is seen here in a portrait by this Venetian pal of his

(6, 4).clue: This Caribbean capital was occupied by the U.S. from 1915 to 1934 & from 1994 to 1995

(1, 5).clue: This independent agency insures individual deposits in banks & savings associations for up to $100,000

(2, 5).clue: The McCallister brothers, one of whom becomes president in 2040

(3, 5).clue: The "original melon liqueur" from Suntory; it'll turn you green with envy

(4, 5).clue: This Philadelphia painter of "Death of Wolfe" headed east to Italy in 1760 to learn new directions in art

(6, 5).clue: A French explorer called this North American island Ile-St.-Jean

(1, 1).clue: This property allows a razor blade to float on water or mercury to gather into globules

(2, 1).clue: In this show, Tony Manero is headed for the disco when he discovers--Oh, no! A cold sore!!

(4, 1).clue: (Sarah of the Clue Crew delivers the clue while demonstrating such a move with Cheryl at a chessboard.)  The knight is well suited to this maneuver, that threatens two pieces at one time; it shares its name with a piece of tableware

(5, 1).clue: A short prayer of thanks said before a meal, it's from the Latin for "favor"

(6, 1).clue: The epithet of this prince, Richard II's father, probably refers to the color of his armor, not the terror he inspired

(1, 2).clue: The pistils of most flowers have 3 main parts: the stigma, the style & this round base where egg cells are formed

(2, 2).clue: ABBA's rockin' musical about the very maternal star of "Rosemary's Baby"

(4, 2).clue: The "Sicilian" one starts with a move by black on the queen's half of the board

(5, 2).clue: This 64-square-mile lake is really just a broad basin of the Jordan River

(6, 2).clue: This Prussian statesman was given the title of Prince in 1871

(1, 3).clue: His 2 laws of genetics are the law of segregation & the law of independent assortment

(2, 3).clue: Mrs. Levi dumps matchmaking & busts out as a voluptuous country singer in this blockbuster

(4, 3).clue: (Cheryl of the Clue Crew delivers the clue while demonstrating in a chess game with Sarah.)  It's the 8-letter term for the direction in which I've chosen to castle

(5, 3).clue: It's the 2-word nickname for the Mongol army that overran Eastern Europe

(6, 3).clue: Austrian prince & foreign minister Metternich arranged a marriage between Napoleon & this archduchess

(1, 4).clue: Of the 6 simple machines, the screw is a spiral version of this other simple machine

(2, 4).clue: Fanny Brice is a laugh riot when she leaves the Follies to sell cookies & earn merit badges in this smash hit

(4, 4).clue: Bring your queen out fast & you can have this victory after just 2 moves

(5, 4).clue: It's not dad's dad, it's a large gray dolphin with a blunt snout

(6, 4).clue: The caravel was developed under the patronage of this man born in 1394

(1, 5).clue: The Crab Nebula in this Zodiac constallation is the remains of the supernova of 1054 A.D.

(2, 5).clue: A Siamese monarch & a governess team up for this ungrammatical salute to the play that inspired "Cabaret"
(2, 5).correct response: The King and I Am a Camera

(4, 5).clue: (Jimmy of the Clue Crew delivers the clue while at a chessboard with Cheryl.)  Even chess masters often begin a game with this familiar opening named for a Spanish priest

(5, 5).clue: He's the cutting-edge composer of works like "Koyaanisqatsi"

(6, 5).clue: While Prince of Novgorod in the 13th century, he became its hero

(0, 0).clue: In 1790 this Midwest city was named for a society that had been named for a Roman citizen-soldier
